title: Do we really not know how the Great Pyramids of Egypt were built? - Quora

response.answer_text: A Big NO for now. Many theories have been made but understandably none of them so far could obtain a consensus from scholars and egyptologists. IMHO, the difficulty to figure out the pyramid building techniques resides on some major elements: Machine vs. Lever: Greek historian Herodotus (500 BC) said that ancient Egyptian priests told him that their ancestors had used some kind of machines. Egyptologists translated them as simple “Levers”!. Why?Ramps vs. No ramps: Herodotus said that ancient Egyptian priests told him that their ancestors had never mentioned about ramps. Most egyptologists and scholars continue to talk about ramps as a central tool! Why?But these assumptions seem to have been debunked already: Muon particle based scanning shows already that there were no internal spiraling ramp inside the Khufu pyramid. Ramps of sand sink. Ramps of stone could not be dismantled: A big gash of Menkaure pyramid caused by a failed attempt in the Middle Age to dismantle this pyramid is a strong evidence of that.Many experiments using levers to raise stone blocks from one stone course to another failed miserably.The unresolved issues raised by these assumed major elements are why, I believe, we get stuck in explaining how the ancient Egyptians built their pyramids So what could be the alternatives to levers and ramps? Here is my attempt. If you are curious about a new theory attempt then keep reading, otherwise you can skip the rest of my answer. Based on my research, what Herodotus reported can be verified. The ancient Egyptian priests did not know in details how their ancestors had built their pyramids because the oral transmission of knowhow could get lost over time (a gap of 2000 years nevertheless) but what these priests reported to Herodotus may have been still accurate: Their ancient Egyptian ancestors did invent “machines” and did build the pyramids from the inside out (therefore no ramps), and from the top down (possible with machines that build the basic layers of stone courses from the bottom up but finish the sophisticated structures from the top down). Based on my research, these invented ancient Egyptian machines could be disguised as mundane structures inside pyramids that we usually call today as corbeled gallery, descending passage, ascending passage, portcullis. Their true roles, based on my theory again, could be very well the same of our modern escalators, elevators, travelators. Their machines were invented to hoist and move stone blocks instead of people for our modern ones. With these inventions, the ancient Egyptian architects would not have needed ramps of any kind to build their pyramids, as a result they could build them using a set of external and internal escalators (therefore from the inside out), and a set of elevators to reach the pyramidion (therefore from the top down afterwards). These invented machines apply a well known principle “Using Earth;s gravity against itself” or counterweight vs. weight. The ancient Egyptians would have invented a simple way to make counterweights as modular and light-weighted units so that the latter can be mounted or unmounted quickly and easily carried by pyramid workers. You might say “No way” or “Nonsense”. But let’s examine some facts that might change your mind. Here is a painting made by an descendant of ancient Egyptians who built the pyramids. A thousand years after the pyramids were built, an ancient Egyptian artist painted a mural in Ramses tomb seems to depict something that might be likened to an escalator with a sledge of items, and not a ramp (Egyptologists explain it as a river with boats):  Now let’s examine whether or not the escalators could exist inside the pyramids. First off, all descending passages were counterweight sliding slopes of escalators to drag stone blocks up to the top of the base of the pyramid. The hieroglyph “pyramid” below seems to indicate that the base of the pyramid is a separate and important entity that must be built first:  All descending passages of pyramids have the same 26+ degree of inclination, the same smoothness of their floor, the same rectilinear slope from top to bottom (1/2 inch of deviation only for the one of Khufu pyramid according to Petrie and other scholars). All entrances of these descending passages are located a certain height (20 to 30 meters) above the ground.The ascending passage and the floor of the Grand Gallery of the Khufu pyramid have exactly the same inclination characteristics of the descending passage. The Khufu pyramid has also a set of trial passages located less than 100 meters away that matches exactly the junction between the ascending passage and descending passage: Why did the architects of the Khufu pyramid need to make such a huge effort to build a sample of passages to try out before building the real ones for just the purpose of a walkway to access the burial chamber? Moreover previous pyramids like the Bent pyramid, the Red pyramid had already similar descending passages!Most descending passages have an end section in shape of a funnel which apparently reduces the diameter of the tunnel bore of the passage therefore can stop stone plugs to slide further down. A pack of three granite stone plugs at the end of the ascending passage of the Khufu pyramid is an evidence of how the funnel-like end section of the passage prevents the granite blocks to slide further down: If these funnels are not there then there are a recess instead that can store a wooden beam to stop the sliding stone blocks. What were the stone plug stoppers for if these passages were only used as walkway?Inside the Khufu pyramid, the ascending passage has four ultra-heavy girdle stones, made each of one piece, that were said to strengthen the passage: Why did the ancient Egyptian architects of this pyramid need to strengthen the ascending passage if the latter was just a walkway? Would the strengthening of the passage make more sense if the passage had been used as a sliding slope for sledges of counterweight stone disks, knowing that stone falling and slipping must have been frequent during the entire construction time.Inside the Khufu pyramid, the ascending passage + the floor of the Grand Gallery + the temporary wooden Bridge between them form a perfect sliding slope for counterweights of a conveyor-belt based escalator. Is it just a coincidence?The two hidden voids discovered by the muon particle based scanning project of French-Japanese scientific teams in 2017 match perfectly the hypothetical horizontal corridor (travelator) that links the outside escalator to the Grand Gallery., and the hidden corridor/escalator above the Grand Gallery to hoist stone blocks to the pyramidion. Is it another coincidence? Some pyramids have even 2 descending passages on the same side, one on top of the other like the Khafre pyramids as shown below: The Menkaure pyramid is similar to the Khafre pyramid in this regard. It has also 2 descending passages on the same side, one on top of the other but the upper one was sealed off.Why did the ancient Egyptian architects need to build two walkways on top of the other to get to exactly the same burial chamber?Inside the descending passages of the Khafre and Menkaure pyramids, there is a long horizontal corridor of these passages that leads to the burial chamber. So why did ancient Egyptian architects not extend this horizontal corridor to the rim of the pyramid, which is much simpler than digging down into the Earth then go horizontal then go up again, and all that to be a walkway only?Why none of descending passages of pyramids were filled up to prevent the tomb robbers to reach the burial chambers, and yet filling them up from the top down would be easy? So why did the ancient Egyptian architects want to facilitate the tasks of the tomb robbers? it would be even worse with the Khafre pyramid or the Bent pyramid: that have two descending passages instead of one!Why did the ancient Egyptian architects make the mouth of descending passage quite up high above the ground so everyone including potential tomb robbers could see the entrance to the burial chamber from very far away and that year in and year out? The tomb robbers would just need to mark them down for their future exploration.There are also many other evidences of these ancient Egyptian inventions. It is too long to present them here. Here are all the links to my book and videos that you might want to explore, should you be interested in my findings and theory: Egyptian Pyramid Escalator-Elevator Theory: Egyptian Pyramids built with Escalators & Elevators - Kindle edition by Nguyen, Antoine Khai. Arts & Photography Kindle eBooks @ Amazon.com

Don’t we? We have managed to reverse engineer most of the techniques they used, and some of it was documented by the Egyptians themselves. We know how they moved massive stone objects, for example, because they left us pictures of it being done:  They also left us a record of how they developed all the techniques required for building a pyramid. You can trace the development of them from the earliest mastaba (“bench”) style tombs, through small step pyramids, up to the final true pyramids:  We’ve even got examples of times they got it wrong, like when they found out they’d made one too steep and had to change the angle half way through:  Nothing they were doing was magic, a lot was just trial and error They made lots of mistakes and the times they got it right it was largely down to three things: Raw numbers of human bodies. Want to drag a huge stone up a ramp? Grab a hundred people and get to it!Good organisational ability that allowed them to control long supply chains and large amounts of specialised manpower over decades on a complex task. Their society was organised, fairly literate and they had a lot of experience.Time. It took decades to build a pyramid.They had a pretty good grip on the basic maths required and were confident building things out of stone. They knew, for example how to correctly mark out and level the foundations for an insanely heavy stone building. They used simple methods like channels filled with water to act as a natural level. We have a lot of documents telling us how they did things. The Egyptians wrote everything relating to their construction down, and some of that has survived to give us details, for example the Diary of Merer. There are still some details about which exact technique they used to solve specific problems that we’re unclear about, but we know a lot of the details and we know the broad outline of the others. The idea that the pyramids are some kind of total mystery is a popular one, but it’s not really very accurate.

I assume you’re talking about these;  Pretty magnificent, eh? There are still some mysteries about the building of them, but the major one that has provided the fodder for ancient aliens, etc. is of course how they would have moved and placed five ton blocks at a pretty steady clip of about one per minute or so. Lots of research has been done on this, and the prevailing theory (it is a theory, but a really good one and provable) is described here; How Ancient Egyptians Moved Massive Pyramid Stones The secret was apparently in the Egyptian sand itself. Scientists found that by wetting the sand in front of the sledges, quite heavy objects can be moved pretty easily.  In effect, the water acts as a lubricant and with a not-unbelievable amount of labor the huge blocks can just slide along the route. The article quoted that it took 192 workers to move each stone - So with an army of about, say, 10,000 workers they would have about 50 blocks en route, and at 24/7, and at 2.3 million blocks, over ten years, that would be 630 large “work shifts” (or “sprints”) - doable…. It might have actually been the first “agile development team” process in history. The article I quoted also says Egyptologists also have found documents related to their construction. And what was actually going on at the site;  There were massive amounts of protein-rich foods consumed by the workers.  The workers lived in barracks.  There was a “project manager” that lived in a 21-room house on the site…  There were bakeries and slaughterhouses at the site(s). So, there is not really a lot of mystery here. BUT - where there is mystery (to me) is WHY they were built. There are over eighty known pyramids in Egypt from the old and middle kingdoms. Some have fairly complex architecture; Not just a “bunch of blocks”    In my mind, if they wanted to just “build a tomb”, they could have just build the damn things, dump the casket in and finish building it and be done with it. Plus, these would be pretty-big advertisements to graverobbers, in my opinion. AND, although I’m not an Egyptologist, I think the Pharaohs were buried in the Valley of Kings. This very question was asked on Quora many times. Here a link to one thread. How many mummies were actually found in the pyramids?

We have a very good idea of how the pyramids were built. The problem of cutting, moving and stacking stones has been solved in many different ways throughout human history. The Egyptians used one or more of the known techniques for moving rocks by human power, which vary from ‘put it on rollers’, ‘drag it with ropes’, ‘push it with levers’, ‘skid it over wet sand or clay’, etc. There are some details we don’t know because they didn’t leave traces and/or had to be demolished after construction. For example, assuming they used ramps, how did they arrange the ramps as the pyramid increased in height. You’d have the same problem looking at a modern building and figuring out how the scaffolding was made. It just isn’t there any more to be examined, because when the building is finished the scaffolding is demolished. The real issue is what I call the ‘mighty whitey’ delusion. When accounts of the pyramids were coming back to northern Europe, the cultural prejudices of Europe led to the conclusion that the ‘primitive, ignorant, dark skinned, subhumans’ living in the region couldn’t possibly have built anything like that. There had to be a secret white race that came there and taught those poor savages how to pile rocks in the shape rocks naturally pile into. If there’s no evidence that mighty whitey taught them how, then it must have been sky visitors. No other explanation… The same thing happened over and over. The stone walls at Gondor in Ethiopia were said to be proof of a lost white race. The stonework at Tiwanaku in Bolivia has been claimed to be proof of a lost white race and/or space aliens. The lines in the desert at Nazca in Peru are said to be proof of aliens, and even proof that some tribe there must have had aircraft or balloons, because the brown people who live there couldn’t possibly plow lines in the dirt, couldn’t possibly have observed the construction from the surrounding hills to help lay out the shapes, and obviously weren’t able to comprehend simple surveying concepts like sighting a line or measuring distance by pacing or using knotted rope. It’s ingrained prejudice, racism, and nationalism.

Edward Leedskalnin knew how the pyramids were built. He then proceeded to prove it, by building his own cosmically aligned megalithic structure. By himself. He called his creation “Rock Gate”. Presently, we call it “Coral castle”. The methods used by him and the Ancients to build such structures are clearly not known to us now. If it is known then it is not shared knowledge. For whatever reason, Ed did not directly disclose how he did it and would not allow anyone to see him working. It may not have been shared knowledge in ancient times either. Evidence suggests that there was a cataclysmic event in our distant past (13,000 years ish) that “reset” the ancient world order, resulting in the loss of much knowledge and life. “We” don’t know how they did it because we can’t be having everyone going around building their own megalithic compounds. It is also likely that with the knowledge of how they were built comes enlightenment. Knowledge is power and power is reserved only for those of a certain status. “We” are only allowed access to technology that would not pose a threat to those in power. “We” are restrained, by any means necessary, from true knowledge, mainly through means of spreading misinformation and seeding confusion. I’d like to see anyone claiming that they/we know how the ancient megalithic sites were built, to prove it. Prove it in similar fashion to the way Edward Leedskalnin did. On the flip side I would also like to see otherwise very intelligent people stop believing things without proof. The language of the universe was very well understood by the ancient builders, as it was with Ed. You don’t need a physics degree to understand and manipulate nature efficiently, you just have to be attentive to the way it speaks. Anyone wanting to know how the ancients cut, transported, and raised such massive stones should study everything Edward Leedskalnin left us with and wrote. We do not know as much as we think we do. There is more folks. It is in your own best interest to understand and verify my words, it matters none to me either way. Oh and one more thing people; stop using “aliens” as an explanation for the unknown. You’d be better off simply admitting that you don’t know. Unless by saying “aliens” you’re referring to “human beings”, in which case the odds of you being correct are greater. This should get you started: Edward Leedskalnin’s Writings / Booklets

To the extent that we can know under the circumstances, we do. Truly. and we’ve known for decades. It’s pretty clear from archaeological evidence that the pyramids were built with blocks of limestone quarried by laborious sawing and splitting, mostly from nearby quarries (but with some special-purpose blocks of stone ferried up the Nile and landed at a small port facility built somewhat inland for better access to the site), pulled up temporary ramps and dragged into position using sleds and log rollers. We’re missing some details. For example, a recent find in a quarry indicated a steeper ramp than previously expected, and a series of holes along the edges implying that pulley-like systems may have been employed to pull from behind as well as in front. We’re similarly in the dark about things like the specific design of the sled or diameter of rollers, but these are, as I say, details. The problem is that we’ve also got a lot of people who simply don’t believe the evidence or the conclusions. There are misconceptions about the quality of the masonry or the size of the stones (most weight no more than a ton or two and are fairly rough masonry with gaps filled by mortar; the really large blocks and fine masonry constitute a small portion of the structure) and a lot of blunt incredulity (there are people who simply “don’t believe” that large stones could have been moved or stunningly fine-quality masonry was technologically possible despite ample historical and experimental evidence that it was). We truly know, but there’s a relevant saying about the Nile...

Why don't we truly know how the pyramids in Egypt were built? This is the kind of archaeological “mystery” given in breathless tones in bad documentaries. “Why was Stonehenge built? And how?” The reality is rather more mundane. The question isn’t really “How did they transport such huge blocks of stone?” but rather “We know of at least three different techniques which could have been used, but from the evidence available we can’t pin down just which one was used.” That’s the sort of detail which is important to historians and archaeologists, but is pretty boring to most people. So it gets played up like a Big Mystery. And the pyramids in particular - huge, ancient, exotic, evocative - are a favorite to trot out, along with “This scientist believes he has solved the riddle!” In truth, we have a remarkable level of detail on the construction of several pyramids - who was the foreman, when construction began, when it was completed, how many workers were on the project, how they were paid (they weren’t slaves, BTW) - all sorts of records of the sort you’d keep on a large public works project. It’s just they didn’t record mundane details, any more than we write down the make and model of the construction crane used to build a skyscraper. Which is sad from an archaeological perspective, but unsurprising. Perhaps a better question is why popular media seems utterly fixated on questions which have such dull answers, and seems unable to move on to other, more interesting questions.

The Egyptian pyramids were Pre-flood structures and that must be its condition in history for all time to come, no more no less. From “Hints for Realistic History” by Balfero we can read: “Except for some survivors who escaped near obliteration from the full fury of the Flood, a discontinuity of knowledge existed for the new people of the world after the cataclysm. The event of the worldwide flood is one of the biggest reasons for the hodgepodge assemblage of ideas persisting and confusing all sorts of people even up to this day. Upon the facts of the Flood, with special attention toward its date of occurrence, one can easily picture that during the time of the great upheaval humankind was almost wiped out on the planet and the continuity of knowledge was cut-off, saving only the memories of those that survived after the cataclysm. Hence the world’s general view of beliefs, ideas and other stories that later become legends, folklore, mythology and even religion must have some conformity in form and style and that most were envisioned only after the end of the flood. The event and time of the flood as a dividing line in world history is a very effective tool for verifying the veracity of other historical events”. Have a nice day and future soon. Thank you.

Unfortunately, we still do not know exactly how the Giza Pyramids were built. However, recent archaeological finds have helped us understand more about the methods they used to construct such grandiose structures. We know that Khufu’s pyramid is precisely oriented north-south to the four cardinal compass directions, and that the pyramid is a mere .05 percent error away from being a perfect square. To achieve a geometrically perfect triangle, it was very critical that they control the angle of inclination on all sides at every stage of construction. The precision of its design in an age where only soft metal tools existed as well as the enormous scale of its construction make it one of the most impressive feats in human engineering. Experts calculate that it would have required men to move 12 blocks every hour around the clock for 20 years to place the 550,000 to 900,000 stones the monument is made of. French Architect Jean-Pierre Houdin proposed his theory that an internal ramp was used midway through construction to continue laying down the limestone blocks as there was no possible way for external ramps to be built high enough to complete it from the outside without them collapsing. While there have been no internal excavations done to prove his theory for fear of destroying the monument, we have only assumptions to go on.

Egyptologists believe the pyramid was built as a tomb for the Fourth Dynasty Egyptian pharaoh Khufu (often Hellenized as "Cheops") and was constructed over a 20-year period. Khufu's vizier, Hemiunu (also called Hemon), is believed by some to be the architect of the Great Pyramid. It is thought that, at construction, the Great Pyramid was originally 146.6 metres (481.0 ft) tall, but with the removal of its original casing, its present height is 137 metres (449.5 ft). The lengths of the sides at the base are difficult to reconstruct, given the absence of the casing, but recent analyses put them in a range between 230.26 metres (755.4 ft) and 230.44 metres (756.0 ft). The volume, including an internal hillock, is roughly 2,300,000 cubic metres (81,000,000 cu ft). The Great Pyramid consists of an estimated 2.3 million blocks which most believe to have been transported from nearby quarries. The Tura limestone used for the casing was quarried across the river. The largest granite stones in the pyramid, found in the "King's" chamber, weigh 25 to 80 tonnes and were transported from Aswan, more than 800 km (500 mi) away. Ancient Egyptians cut stone into rough blocks by hammering grooves into natural stone faces, inserting wooden wedges, then soaking these with water. As the water was absorbed, the wedges expanded, breaking off workable chunks. Once the blocks were cut, they were carried by boat either up or down the Nile Riverto the pyramid. It is estimated that 5.5 million tonnes of limestone, 8,000 tonnes of granite (imported from Aswan), and 500,000 tonnes of mortar were used in the construction of the Great Pyramid. Many alternative, often contradictory, theories have been proposed regarding the pyramid's construction techniques. Many disagree on whether the blocks were dragged, lifted, or even rolled into place. The Greeks believed that slave labour was used, but modern discoveries made at nearby workers' camps associated with construction at Giza suggest that it was built instead by tens of thousands of skilled workers. Verner posited that the labour was organized into a hierarchy, consisting of two gangs of 100,000 men, divided into five zaa or phyle of 20,000 men each, which may have been further divided according to the skills of the workers. One mystery of the pyramid's construction is its planning. John Romer suggests that they used the same method that had been used for earlier and later constructions, laying out parts of the plan on the ground at a 1-to-1 scale. He writes that "such a working diagram would also serve to generate the architecture of the pyramid with precision unmatched by any other means". He also argues for a 14-year time-span for its construction. A modern construction management study, in association with Mark Lehner and other Egyptologists, estimated that the total project required an average workforce of about 14,500 people and a peak workforce of roughly 40,000. Without the use of pulleys, wheels, or iron tools, they used critical path analysis methods, which suggest that the Great Pyramid was completed from start to finish in approximately 10 years at a rate of up to 3 blocks per minute on certain levels. So we do know.

We get all kinds of things wrong about the pyramids. Slave labor.No. The works on the pyramids were citizens doing the work of the Gods. In the building of a temple-tomb for there God-King.They were paid.They themselves often paid for basic mummification.There are worker tombs around the pyramids.Alien - - .Are you insane. It was difficult. But twenty years. People willing to worker themselves beyond reason. Past collect experience.The pyramids got bigger. Because there is a past historical record of how to build the things.The first were crude. As they learned they got better. New ways to build discovered.The first test structures of pyramids are other buried out there. Or dismantled.The Chrysler building was not the first tall building.It took a period of learning how to build them.It was no different with pyramids.Do we not know exact details on somethings.Yes. The building was thousands of years ago.Most records are gone. What we have are the structures.Egypt does not want us to dismantle one of them to learn details.Please go to PBS and National Geographic sites for videos.

Yes, we are far behind their ancient advanced technology and science. If we can manage to lift one piece of stone weighs 70 ton and place it exactly in its predefined location and position, then continue adding more stones weighs two to fifteen ton each, with zero space between each other and without any materials, definitely they have advanced technology and science to do this advanced type of engineering, architecture and building engineering. Another important part of the building process is the choosing the location to suit the purpose of your building. The location is accurately chosen to be exactly in the center of the five continents. The location is another question here. The relationship with the outer space is another puzzle. The entry path to the pyramid points to the North Pole with high accuracy we just discovered recently, the mathematical relations that relate dimensions of the Pyramid to golden ratio that scientists of today's modern knowledge and advanced science came to know it recently (relatively) . Yes we can not figure out how they built it; moreover why they build it?

There is one answer which most will not like, and that is that those that built the Pyramids were smarter than those that can,t work how it was done, they had ways of doing thing that we can,t even Imagine, the Answer is slave labour Hard work and an inventive brain, they had wheals, leavers, ropes, and counter balances, but a few, don,t even realise that we moved large weights over many miles, in simple canals, there is nothing to say the didn't do the same, after all the Nile was at their disposal, use water as the counter weight on your lifting beams, 20 men could carry water to lift these 6 to 10 tone blocks or use it as counter wight to slide the blocks up one side of the pyramid as the counter weight the down the other, I have used this type of primitive crane to erect a tower in the past works very well, there is no limit to what an active mind can do.  The only true way to know how it was done, was to have been there, or except what is recorded, but we are to smart to except that, because we just don’t know.

Levers, lubricants, ramps and muscle power. We don't know exactly how they built them in the same way we don't know exactly how the Pantheon in Rome was built, but we have a pretty good idea of the general methods thy used. Plus, we can see the evolution of pyramids in the earlier ones and get an idea. We don't need precise, day by day records of how every block was lifted, transported and installed to know that Egyptian laborers did it and very smart engineers designed them. No ET or lost civilizations needed. If it makes someone feel better to think they were built by aliens (imagine an alien civilization traveling the stars just to pile rocks, would we do it?) can knock themselves out. I prefer the truth. I'd be thrilled to be proven wrong on the existence of aliens, but they are not here. Between the thrill of a fable and the sobriety of thrush I'll always prefer the latter.

Since you changed the question - we do. Cut rocks into blocks. Make layer of blocks. Make another layer of blocks on top of the first, slightly smaller. Repeat. Humans have been cutting stone for a good ten thousand years. They've been moving stone probably for longer. And constructing things out of blocks goes back that far too. So the Egyptians, after a good five, six thousand years of practice making things out of stone, to build the Great Pyramid required expert masons, which they had, good logistics and transportation, which they had (thanks to the Nile right next to the site) and the wealth to afford to keep thousands of men working on a project such as this, which - whoo- boy - did Egypt have. Original answer to “Do we finally know who built the pyramids?” - Yes. The Egyptians. We've known that for about a 4,500 years now.

Because people don’t build pyramids anymore. Even the Egyptians stopped building pyramids and opted for digging tomb complexes for their kings. Knowledge not used is knowledge lost. Also, not that much literature and written records survived from ancient Egypt, and a lot of the ones that did are mostly historical records and religious literature written by the court and priesthood. Both don’t really care about the know how on building a pyramid. Also, not many wooden stuff remained due to deterioration. Wood is a versatile material that is important in construction and most likely used to create supports and building contraptions during the construction of the pyramids. But wood decomposed and a lot of said wooden contraptions are mainly a one time thing. Meaning, they were tossed aside after a pyramid was finished or used for other uses (like firewood for cooking).

No, we know. The blocks of stone were floated in by barge. The great pyramids were then built with a ramp spiralling around them up which the blocks were dragged or pushed to build ever higher, then at the end the ramp was covered over and blended in.

response.answer_text: Yeah, we originally assumed they were built by tens of thousands of slaves, and anthropologists demonstrated techniques by which tens of thousands of slaves could build pyramids. Then we began to realize that fewer slaves were involved, and anthropologists went back to the historical drawing board, and figured out ways that rather small numbers of workers could build them.

They were built about 4,500 years ago, There are about 2.2 million blocks of rock, and it was built in 20 years like they say, that means that they had to put a new piece every two and half minutes 24/7. Their average weight is 4.5 tons. There are only three believable theories. It was built by some higher intelligence and technology people (creatures) from some place else, orThey used high sound waves that repealed the gravity and levitated the rocks into their right place. OrThe building blocks were cast on the spot; made of extremely hardening concrete with some unknown ingredients.I don’t believe jews or Egyptians built it with bare hands. Besides, the pyramid is full of amazing mathematical proportions like Pi, Pythagorean theorem, Phi and many others. See my detailed account in another answer,

Some of the workers that helped build the pyramids left graffiti in hidden places on the pyramids. From what we know they used groups of 30,000 people in different shifts and several others to fill other positions such as overseers of the work cooks, janitorial, and other positions as needed. In all it was 100,000 people over 10 years. Keep in mind this doesn't throw out theories of advanced technology either. Archaeologist have had hard time explaining away the schist disk. Just because they lived back then doesn't mean they didn't have knowledge of things we didn't know or technologies.

We do. The only thing we don’t really know is whether the ramp that was used to raise the stones was one long straight one or one in a spiral that went around the pyramid. Seriously, there is no big mystery. The quarries are right beside them.

response.answer_text: We do. The idea that we don’t is a fairy tale made up to sell books about how it must’ve been space aliens or something. Solved! How Ancient Egyptians Moved Massive Pyramid Stones How Were the Egyptian Pyramids Built?

No, we know how they were built. There are no particular mysteries left there. Well, ok, there's one. We know that some artefacts in the pyramids show clear signs the Egyptians had differential gears. We do not know if they invented them or if it's a Hellenic idea that they obtained. We know the Hellenic people had them, we have the artefacts and written histories to prove it. That's it. That's the one thing we don't yet know. Who came up with that one specific idea. Everything else was sorted years ago.

Yes, we really don’t. There are some smug “scientist” types that think they have it figured out, but this is based on arrogance and lack of perspective regarding ancient history. Many scientists assume they are the best and brightest of the best and brightest age. It’s a huge phucking assumption, but they live by it. They just can’t accept that perhaps we modern apes just aren’t the best earth has ever produced.

Why don't we truly know how the pyramids in Egypt were built? Well we know the carved the stones and were from, transported them and built the pyramids. Its just the question of what techniques were used. Well the pyramids were built a very long time ago and the records of how they made them has not survived nor have any artefacts that could shed light on the methods. Well outside of a few painting in tombs etc. This means that the only method left is to look at the tools and resources the Egyptians had at the time and see what possible methods they could have used. This results in a list of possible methods and we have no way of telling which ones they actually used to do so.

We know fully well how the ancient peoples built the structures. It isn't rocket science. It is dedicated people working long and hard to build whatever it is that they wanted to build. It's embarrassing, and irritating, that modern men question their achievements and belittle them. Don't take my word for this. Look at the evidence in archeological research. No ancient structure was built by anyone but the ancient people.

They were of course built by aliens. They started building tombs with mud brick until one decide to build with stone, and got a bit carried away building one on top of the other until it had formed a step pyramid. Other aliens had their turn at building pyramids sometime two or three before they were happy with the result. Some collapsed and one had the angle altered to prevent collapse but eventually they got it right Not bad for aliens who only had wood, stone, and copper tools. It helped they had a large well organised and fed workforce with architects and engineers led by a god king who didnt have to answer to anybody. Or then again perhaps not.

Everyone is different, but I’d put everyone who doesn’t know into one of two broad categories: The apathetic. They don’t know because they don’t care. This is fine, pyramids aren’t going to interest everyone.The aggressively ignorant. They don’t know because rejecting the typical explanations as the “party line” makes them feel smarter. They tend to be crackpots in more ways than one.

You mean apart from Ancient Egyptian writings concerning their construction, the clues given in the physical structure of the pyramids, apart from various histories recounting their construction? You know, evidence?

No drawings nor writings were found explaining the mechanism and approach towards building such a huge Pyramid. All theories today are sort of a reverse engineering trying to derive the mechanism used based on best known practices from Civil engineering and the tools and building blocks. Did the Pharaoh(s) intend to hide the “Knowhow” to protect the tombs inside ? Sounds very much possible, but which means the Knowhow will remain hidden and an endless secret like today .

It was never a secret. The Egyptians made them, with some straightforward engineering, local rock, and a lot of paid labor. They made them as tombs for their pharoahs. Every time non-whacked-out archeology looks at them, this gets underlined yet again.

We always had a good idea who built them. And yes, we “finally” know exactly who they were, because they made sure we knew, by carving it in stone. So as soon as we had learned how to read hieroglyphs, we knew for sure.

That is correct, we don’t know. The techniques are apparently lost. We also can’t really read hieroglyphs that well. It is confusing, and changes over time, apparently. If humanity survives for another few thousand years, this post will probably be unintelligible, as well.

We do know. Pretty much exactly. The pyramid builders left diagrams and explanations. The rest we can figure out. We know from reading evidence that was recorded, that the Egyptians knew all the engineering necessary.

Large blocks were brought via boats on Nile and then dragged/ pushed over sand sloped. They used various techniques to reduce friction. wooden rollers over flat timbers. Another was to encircle the stone with wood framework to make it move like a wheel. As the pyramid went up higher, the sand slope was also changed to match. This is what has been conjectured.

much easier to build a square spiral ramp inside the finished sides of your pyramid. That way you can establish the top of your pyramid and get the corners to line up. You stack blocks on top of your ramp as you build out the pyramid to the finished sides from the top down (remove the tilted portions of the ramp that go between tiers). Much less effort and less material needed for the ramp. Put your limestone facing blocks on at that time too...
No
